title.narrative: OUTPUT 1.1.3: SOCIAL NORMS AND COMMUNITIES PRACTICES IN HEALTH

description.narrative: By 2025, in northern and most disadvantaged areas, resilient communities adhere to practices and social norms that promotematernal, new-born, child, and adolescent health., which contributes to Fast-Track The End Of Hiv/Aids, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Operations Support To Programme Delivery, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Innovation, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2025, pregnant women, new-borns, children, and adolescents, especially the most disadvantaged, make full use of integrated quality services in health centres and at the community level.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2025, in northern and most disadvantaged areas, resilient communities adhere to practices and social norms thatpromotematernal, new-born, child, and adolescent health.

description.narrative: The CO reinforced the capacity of community health workers (CHWs) and supported village-level multisectoral ‘quality improvement’ committees in three health districts as part of the first phase of the child-friendly community (CFC) approach implemented in that CO intervention area. As a result, 85.6 per cent (601,158 of 702,215) targeted households adopted at least six essential family practices (EFPs). | Status:Partially met | As-of Date:18/01/2022
